title: 2011–12 Pro12
text:
The 2011–12 <a href="Pro14">Pro12 League</a> (also known as the "RaboDirect Pro12" for sponsorship reasons) was the 11th season of the <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> competition originally known as the <a href="Pro14">Celtic League</a>, the second with its current 12-team format, and also the first with <a href="RaboDirect">RaboDirect</a> as title sponsor.
The twelve teams competing were the four Irish provinces, <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a>, <a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a>, <a href="Connacht%20Rugby">Connacht</a> and <a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a>; two Scottish regions, <a href="Edinburgh%20Rugby">Edinburgh Rugby</a> and <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a>; four Welsh regions, <a href="Cardiff%20Blues">Cardiff Blues</a>, <a href="Dragons%20%28rugby%20union%29">Newport Gwent Dragons</a>, <a href="Ospreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">Ospreys</a> and <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a>; and two Italian clubs <a href="Aironi">Aironi</a> and <a href="Benetton%20Rugby">Benetton Treviso</a>.
The competition was won by Ospreys, who defeated Leinster in the final 31–30.
Fixtures.
All times are local.
Leading scorers.
Note: Flags to the left of player names indicate national team as has been defined under <a href="International%20Rugby%20Board">IRB</a> eligibility rules, or primary nationality for players who have not yet earned international senior caps. Players may hold one or more non-IRB nationalities.
Top try scorers.
2011/2012 Dream Team
Broadcasting rights.
<a href="Setanta%20Sports%20Australia">Setanta Sports Australia</a> broadcasts live RaboDirect Pro12 matches in Australia.
<a href="Setanta%20Sports%20Asia">Setanta Sports Asia</a> broadcast live RaboDirect Pro12 matches in Asia also.
